Is it similar for Firefox or other browsers?,While Chrome and Firefox both support similar concepts and events for tab management in their extension APIs, the specific event names and syntax may differ. Here's a comparison of the corresponding events in Firefox's WebExtensions API:chrome.tabs.onCreated (Chrome) ‚ûú browser.tabs.onCreated (Firefox)This event is triggered when a new tab is created.chrome.tabs.onUpdated (Chrome) ‚ûú browser.tabs.onUpdated (Firefox)This event is fired when a tab is updated, such as when the URL or title of the tab changes, or when the tab's loading state changes.chrome.tabs.onRemoved (Chrome) ‚ûú browser.tabs.onRemoved (Firefox)This event is triggered when a tab is closed or removed.In Firefox's WebExtensions API, you can use the browser.tabs namespace and the corresponding event names to register event listeners for tab-related changes.It's worth noting that while the basic functionality and concepts are similar between browsers, there may be slight differences in the available properties or behaviors of the tab-related events. Therefore, it's recommended to consult the official documentation for the specific browser's extension API that you are targeting to ensure accurate implementation.",[],Chrome Extension Tab IDs_https://github.com/gioxx/MarvellousSuspender/discussions/213#discussioncomment-6207346,False,,2023-06-18T02:59:49Z,False,0.0,JavaScript,gioxx/MarvellousSuspender,2023-06-18T04:04:45Z,0.0,Chrome Extension Tab IDs,"Greetings Community!

What tab properties can I normally read browsers' APIs?,The tab properties that you can typically read using browsers' extension APIs include:id: A unique identifier assigned to each tab.url: The URL of the tab's current webpage.title: The title of the tab's current webpage.index: The position of the tab within its window.pinned: Indicates whether the tab is pinned or not.active: Indicates whether the tab is currently active or not.favIconUrl: The URL of the tab's favicon (website icon).status: The loading status of the tab, such as ""loading"", ""complete"", or ""unresponsive"".windowId: The unique identifier of the window that contains the tab.These are some of the commonly accessed properties for tab objects in browsers' extension APIs. The specific API documentation for the browser you are targeting will provide more detailed information about the available properties and their exact names.It's important to note that different browsers or API versions may have slight variations in the available tab properties or provide additional properties that offer more specialized functionality. Therefore, it's recommended to refer to the official documentation of the specific browser and version you are working with for precise information on tab properties.",[],Chrome Extension Tab IDs_https://github.com/gioxx/MarvellousSuspender/discussions/213#discussioncomment-6207346,False,,2023-06-18T02:59:49Z,False,0.0,JavaScript,gioxx/MarvellousSuspender,2023-06-18T04:04:45Z,0.0,Chrome Extension Tab IDs,"Greetings Community!

,213.0,https://github.com/gioxx/MarvellousSuspender/discussions/213,en
Can I add custom properties to tab objects, such as an ID generated by my extension?

Will those persist?","No, you cannot directly add custom properties to the tab objects provided by the browser's extension APIs. The tab objects returned by the APIs are read-only, and any modifications you make to them will not persist or be saved by the browser.However, you can use other approaches to associate custom data or identifiers with tabs in your extension:Persistent Storage: You can use the chrome.storage API (Chrome) or the browser.storage API (Firefox) to store custom data related to tabs. This allows you to save and retrieve information associated with specific tab identifiers or other unique identifiers you generate within your extension. The stored data will persist even when the browser is restarted.External Data Structure: You can maintain an external data structure within your extension (e.g., an array or object) that maps custom identifiers to tab objects or other tab-related data. This allows you to associate custom properties or IDs with tabs and keep track of them within your extension. However, you would need to manage this data structure and ensure synchronization with the tab objects when relevant events occur (e.g., tab creation, removal, or updates).By using these techniques, you can effectively associate custom properties or IDs with tabs in your extension and persistently store the associated data even across browser restarts.",[],Free App Logging Alternatives_https://github.com/ubiquity/ubiquibot/discussions/334#discussioncomment-6018173,False,,2023-05-27T09:25:22Z,,,TypeScript,ubiquity/ubiquibot,2023-05-27T10:54:04Z,1.0,Free App Logging Alternatives,"https://t.me/UbiquityDAO/29891/30084

Currently they appear in a frame which needs to be expanded,"To layout plots on the page in Quarto books, you can use the YAML front matter in your Markdown file or configure it through the configuration file. Here's an example of how you can control the layout of plots using the YAML front matter:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Here is some more text.[CODE_BLOCK_1]","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'markdown', 'Content': '---
title: My Book
---

# Chapter 1

Here is some text.

```{r, fig.cap=""Example plot"", fig.align=""center"", fig.width=6, fig.height=4}
plot(x, y)
'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_1]', 'Type': 'markdown', 'Content': '
In the above example:

- `fig.cap` sets the caption for the plot.
- `fig.align` sets the alignment of the plot on the page. It can be set to `""left""`, `""right""`, or `""center""`.
- `fig.width` and `fig.height` specify the dimensions of the plot in inches.

You can adjust these parameters based on your requirements to control the placement and size of the plots.

Additionally, you can refer to the Quarto documentation for more information on configuring the layout and styling of plots in your Quarto book: https://quarto.org/docs/configuration/

Thanks! Is there code that will automatically size the plots to the page dimensions?,"Yes, Quarto provides options to automatically size the plots to the page dimensions. You can use the fig.fullwidth and fig.fullheight options to achieve this. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Here is some more text.[CODE_BLOCK_1]","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'markdown', 'Content': '---
title: My Book
---

# Chapter 1

Here is some text.

```{r, fig.cap=""Example plot"", fig.align=""center"", fig.fullwidth=true, fig.fullheight=true}
plot(x, y)
'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_1]', 'Type': 'vbnet', 'Content': ""
In the above example, `fig.fullwidth` and `fig.fullheight` are set to `true`, which tells Quarto to automatically adjust the plot size to fill the available width and height of the page.

By setting these options, you don't need to specify explicit dimensions for the plots, and Quarto will handle the sizing for you.

Remember to adjust the other options like `fig.align` and `fig.cap` as per your desired layout and styling preferences.

For more details on configuring and customizing plots in Quarto, you can refer to the Quarto documentation: https://quarto.org/docs/configuration/
""}]",Confirm Dialog on Popstate_https://github.com/inertiajs/inertia/discussions/1648#discussioncomment-6740158,False,,2023-08-14T17:40:19Z,False,1.0,PHP,inertiajs/inertia,2023-08-16T12:21:43Z,1.0,Confirm Dialog on Popstate,"### Versions:

Currently, Inertia does not provide a specific event hook for intercepting and canceling browser back and forward navigation. While the library allows capturing in-page navigation, handling navigation through the browser's back and forward buttons is not directly supported. This limitation poses challenges for scenarios such as warning users about unsaved changes, as well as other contexts where controlling or canceling back and forward navigation is necessary.
The expected behavior would be to have a way within Inertia to easily detect and optionally cancel back and forward navigation, possibly through specific events or hooks designed for this purpose.
1. **Create a component with unsaved changes state**: Create a form with some input fields, and use a state to track whether there are unsaved changes.
2. **Modify without saving**: Modify the input without saving, thus setting the unsaved changes state to true.
3. **Attempt to navigate away**: Use the browser's back or forward buttons to attempt navigation away from the page.
4. **No handling for unsaved changes**: Observe that there is no built-in way within Inertia to intercept this navigation, warn the user, or cancel the navigation.

The absence of an event hook or mechanism within Inertia to handle browser back and forward navigation necessitates workarounds, such as using the `popstate` event, which may interfere with other client-side routing logic.
export default function useUnsavedChanges(active: boolean): void {
const confirmed = window.confirm('You have unsaved changes! Are you sure you want to leave?')

```",Add event hook for cancelable browser back and forward navigation,comments.body,"You're right, but according to this 'very reliable' source, pushing the same state back should work: https://chat.openai.com/share/00d4058e-bbd1-46eb-8543-95a436bf613f

At least I'd like to be able to cancel the functions Inertia executes with this event to implement my own hack. Normally, the browser would dispatch an unload event when using normal navigation. So, I think it should be possible to replicate the same functionality.

I'm building an editor with react flow and if the user moves left, the native back even in the browser is sometimes triggered by accident and the complete state is gone :/",1648.0,https://github.com/inertiajs/inertia/discussions/1648,en

When history popstate is not called? So normal navigation is used. Is the before unload event than dispatched?,"Yes, when the user performs a normal navigation (e.g., by clicking on a link or entering a new URL), the beforeunload event is typically dispatched. This event allows you to show a confirmation dialog to the user before they navigate away from the current page. The purpose of this event is to give the user an opportunity to confirm their intent to leave the page, especially if they have unsaved changes.However, it's important to note that the beforeunload event and the popstate event serve slightly different purposes. The beforeunload event is mainly used to handle user-initiated navigation, while the popstate event is triggered when the user navigates using the browser's back or forward buttons, or when you programmatically change the history state using history.pushState() or history.replaceState().Keep in mind that browser behavior and event dispatch can vary, so it's always a good practice to thoroughly test your code across different browsers to ensure consistent behavior.",[],EVM Slots ‚â† EVM Words_https://github.com/sablier-labs/v2-core/discussions/552#discussioncomment-6264652,True,2023-06-25T09:46:47Z,2023-06-16T14:57:58Z,False,1.0,Solidity,sablier-labs/v2-core,2023-06-25T09:46:47Z,1.0,EVM Slots ‚â† EVM Words,"As of now, only the structs that are known to later be initialized and kept in contract `storage` have the information about how much memory (slots-wise) they occupy. I suggest using the term ""word""/""EVM word"" (instead of ""slot"") and having this information for all of the structs in `DataTypes.sol`.
The advantages of this approach are:

2. the removed burden of having to have the knowledge of the specific uses of the structs declared in `DataTypes.sol`, which increases the coupling between the declarations and the definitions of the structs (i.e. the exact opposite of the motivation for the existence of `DataTypes.sol`).",Uniform markups for the memory requirements of structs declared in DataTypes.sol,comments.body,"It turns out that we cannot use the term ""word"" to refer to storage slots, because ""word"" refers only to memory and stack variables. See my conversation with ChatGPT4 for more details:

What we could do is add the term ""word"" in all structs that are used only in memory, but this may also lead to a confusing state of affairs.",552.0,https://github.com/sablier-labs/v2-core/discussions/552,en

In the Ethereum Virtual Machine, is the term "slot" equivalent to "word" when referring to storage slots? that is, can I refer to storage slots as "EVM words"?,"In the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM), the terms ""slot"" and ""word"" are not exactly the same, and they should not be used interchangeably.A ""slot"" refers to a unit of storage on the EVM. Each slot is 32 bytes (or 256 bits) in size. The EVM's storage is a key-value store where each key is a 256-bit number and each value is a 256-bit number, where the key can be thought of as the slot's index and the value is what is stored in that slot.On the other hand, a ""word"" in EVM terminology is also a 32-byte (256-bit) unit, but it is used in a different context. ""Words"" often refer to units of data used in memory or on the stack, as well as for the data passed to and returned by function calls. When EVM instructions operate on data, they do so on these ""words"".So, while both ""slots"" and ""words"" are 256-bit units, they are used in different contexts - ""slots"" for storage and ""words"" for data manipulation, memory, and function calls. They are not generally referred to interchangeably. Calling a storage slot an ""EVM word"" could cause confusion.",[],Powerwall Dashboard to Kubernetes_https://github.com/jasonacox/Powerwall-Dashboard/discussions/324#discussioncomment-6473844,False,,2023-07-17T05:20:17Z,False,1.0,Python,jasonacox/Powerwall-Dashboard,2023-07-21T17:57:39Z,1.0,Powerwall Dashboard to Kubernetes,"Hi Jason, I am currently using Truenas Core, and a VM on the box to host my powerwall-dashboard and its working really well, but i'd like to move to truenas scale which has built in containerisation etc. would it be possible to break this down into bite sized chucks to do this? I'm thinking is it possible to create a Kubernetes image that contains all the parts i need to be able to run it?

,TrueNas Scale and powerwall-dashboard,comments.body,Hi @Craig-G-NZ !  This is absolutely possible. I don't have a Truenas device so I can't help develop this, but I'm sure others out there would appreciate hearing your adventure.

To start, I suspect Truenas requires you to define each container. You can look at the `powerwall.yml` file as the key setup file to inform how to set up the rest (it references environmental config files you will need to use as well).

I asked ChatGPT to convert our `powerwall.yml` docker-compose file into a script with separate docker runs. I then asked it if it could convert it to a kubernetes manifest.  This may help with your adventure. To be fair, I'm sure there is some errors here but it was rather impressive to see what this AI could do.
Example Kubernetes manifest for Influxdb (see the [chat link ](tps://chat.openai.com/share/c70ac870-b8c9-4d58-b1c5-47d5f6e49332)for the rest):

There is no IoState_protoWithInitFunction,"I apologize for the confusion earlier. In Io language, there isn't a IoState_protoWithInitFunction function to bind C function to Io methods.Instead, you will need to use Io's C API functions to create a new Io method and bind it to your C function. Below is the corrected version of your code:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this code, we define a method table with the ""hello"" C function, and add this method to the ""lobby"" object, which is the global namespace in Io. Then we can call this function by its name in Io.Please note, in the line IoMethodTable methodTable[] = {{""hello"", hello}, {NULL, NULL}}

version: "3.5"

services:
    influxdb:
        image: influxdb:1.8
        container_name: influxdb
        hostname: influxdb
        restart: always
        volumes:
            - type: bind
              source: ./influxdb.conf
              target: /etc/influxdb/influxdb.conf
              read_only: true
            - type: bind
              source: ./influxdb
              target: /var/lib/influxdb
        ports:
            - target: 8086
              published: 8086
              mode: host

    pypowerwall:
        image: jasonacox/pypowerwall:0.6.2t26
        container_name: pypowerwall
        hostname: pypowerwall
        restart: always
        user: "1000:1000"
        ports:
            - target: 8675
              published: 8675
              mode: host
        env_file:
            - pypowerwall.env

    telegraf:
        image: telegraf:1.26.1
        container_name: telegraf
        hostname: telegraf
        restart: always
        user: "1000:1000"
        command: [
            "telegraf",
            "--config",
            "/etc/telegraf/telegraf.conf",
            "--config-directory",
            "/etc/telegraf/telegraf.d"
        ]
        volumes:
            - type: bind
              source: ./telegraf.conf
              target: /etc/telegraf/telegraf.conf
              read_only: true
            - type: bind
              source: ./telegraf.local
              target: /etc/telegraf/telegraf.d/local.conf
              read_only: true
        depends_on:
            - influxdb
            - pypowerwall

    grafana:
        image: grafana/grafana:9.1.2-ubuntu
        container_name: grafana
        hostname: grafana
        restart: always
        user: "${GRAFANAUSER}"
        volumes:
            - type: bind
              source: ./grafana
              target: /var/lib/grafana
        ports:
            - target: 9000
              published: 9000
              mode: host
        env_file:
            - grafana.env
        depends_on:
            - influxdb

    weather411:
        image: jasonacox/weather411:0.2.1
        container_name: weather411
        hostname: weather411
        restart: always
        user: "1000:1000"
        volumes:
            - type: bind
              source: ./weather
              target: /var/lib/weather
              read_only: true
        ports:
            - target: 8676
              published: 8676
              mode: host
        environment:
            - WEATHERCONF=/var/lib/weather/weather411.conf
        depends_on:
            - influxdb,"Sure! To build these containers using a script, we can create a bash script to handle the build and run commands. Let's name the script build_containers.sh. This script will build the images and start the containers based on the services defined in your docker-compose.yml.Here's the build_containers.sh script:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Instructions:Replace /path/to/your/docker-compose-directory with the actual path to the directory containing your docker-compose.yml file.Save the script in a file named build_containers.sh.Make the script executable with the command: chmod +x build_containers.sh.Make sure you have Docker and Docker Compose installed on your system.How to use the script:Open a terminal in the directory where you saved the build_containers.sh file.Run the script with the command: ./build_containers.sh.The script will go through each service defined in your docker-compose.yml, build the respective Docker image, and then start the containers using the docker-compose up command.Note: Before running the script, ensure that the necessary configuration files and environment files mentioned in the docker-compose.yml are present in the correct directories relative to the script location.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'bash', 'Content': '#!/bin/bash\n\n# Function to build and run a container\nbuild_and_run() {\n    service_name=$1\n    docker-compose build $service_name\n    docker-compose up -d $service_name\n}\n\n# Move to the directory containing the docker-compose.yml file\ncd /path/to/your/docker-compose-directory\n\n# Build and run each service\nbuild_and_run influxdb\nbuild_and_run pypowerwall\nbuild_and_run telegraf\nbuild_and_run grafana\nbuild_and_run weather411\n'}]",Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Can you convert it from docker-compose to docker run?,"Sure! We can convert the docker-compose.yml file to individual docker run commands for each service. The docker run commands will build and run the containers one by one.Here's the equivalent docker run script:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Instructions:Replace /path/to/your/docker-compose-directory with the actual path to the directory containing your docker-compose.yml file and the necessary configuration files.Save the script in a file named docker_run_containers.sh.Make the script executable with the command: chmod +x docker_run_containers.sh.Make sure you have Docker installed on your system.How to use the script:Open a terminal in the directory where you saved the docker_run_containers.sh file.Run the script with the command: ./docker_run_containers.sh.The script will use individual docker run commands to build and run the containers one after the other. Please note that the docker run commands use the same configuration options as the original docker-compose.yml file. However, if you need to make any adjustments or modifications to the container configuration, you can do so directly in the docker run commands in the script.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'bash', 'Content': '#!/bin/bash

# Move to the directory containing the necessary configuration files
cd /path/to/your/docker-compose-directory

# Run InfluxDB container
docker run -d \
    --name influxdb \
    --hostname influxdb \
    --restart always \
    -v $(pwd)/influxdb.conf:/etc/influxdb/influxdb.conf:ro \
    -v $(pwd)/influxdb:/var/lib/influxdb \
    -p 8086:8086 \
    influxdb:1.8

# Run pypowerwall container
docker run -d \
    --name pypowerwall \
    --hostname pypowerwall \
    --restart always \
    --user ""1000:1000"" \
    -p 8675:8675 \
    --env-file $(pwd)/pypowerwall.env \
    jasonacox/pypowerwall:0.6.2t26

# Run Telegraf container
docker run -d \
    --name telegraf \
    --hostname telegraf \
    --restart always \
    --user ""1000:1000"" \
    -v $(pwd)/telegraf.conf:/etc/telegraf/telegraf.conf:ro \
    -v $(pwd)/telegraf.local:/etc/telegraf/telegraf.d/local.conf:ro \
    --env-file $(pwd)/telegraf.env \
    --network container:influxdb \
    --network container:pypowerwall \
    telegraf:1.26.1 \
    telegraf --config /etc/telegraf/telegraf.conf --config-directory /etc/telegraf/telegraf.d

# Run Grafana container
docker run -d \
    --name grafana \
    --hostname grafana \
    --restart always \
    --user ""${GRAFANAUSER}"" \
    -v $(pwd)/grafana:/var/lib/grafana \
    -p 9000:9000 \
    --env-file $(pwd)/grafana.env \
    --network container:influxdb \
    grafana/grafana:9.1.2-ubuntu

# Run weather411 container
docker run -d \
    --name weather411 \
    --hostname weather411 \
    --restart always \
    --user ""1000:1000"" \
    -v $(pwd)/weather:/var/lib/weather:ro \
    -p 8676:8676 \
    -e WEATHERCONF=/var/lib/weather/weather411.conf \
    --network container:influxdb \
    jasonacox/weather411:0.2.1
'}]",Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

can you convert it to a kubernetes file?,"Sure! To convert the services defined in your docker-compose.yml file into a Kubernetes manifest, we'll create a Kubernetes Deployment for each service. Additionally, we'll need to set up Persistent Volumes and Persistent Volume Claims to replace the bind mounts used in Docker Compose. Finally, we'll create a Service for each Deployment to expose the containers internally within the Kubernetes cluster.Here's the Kubernetes manifest for the services:InfluxDB Deployment:[CODE_BLOCK_0]InfluxDB ConfigMap:[CODE_BLOCK_1]InfluxDB PersistentVolumeClaim:[CODE_BLOCK_2]pypowerwall Deployment:[CODE_BLOCK_3]pypowerwall ConfigMap:[CODE_BLOCK_4]Telegraf Deployment:[CODE_BLOCK_5]Telegraf ConfigMap:[CODE_BLOCK_6]Telegraf Local ConfigMap:[CODE_BLOCK_7]Grafana Deployment:[CODE_BLOCK_8]Grafana ConfigMap:[CODE_BLOCK_9]weather411 Deployment:[CODE_BLOCK_10]Service for each Deployment (InfluxDB, pypowerwall, telegraf, grafana, and weather411):[CODE_BLOCK_11]Please replace /path/to/your/docker-compose-directory with the actual path to your configuration files. Each service's Deployment creates a pod with a single container running the specified image, and the Service makes the container accessible internally within the Kubernetes cluster.Note: The Kubernetes manifest assumes that you have created appropriate configuration files (e.g., influxdb.conf, telegraf.conf, etc.) and environment files (e.g.,","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'yaml', 'Content': 'apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: influxdb
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: influxdb
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: influxdb
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: influxdb
        image: influxdb:1.8
        ports:
        - containerPort: 8086
        volumeMounts:
        - name: influxdb-conf
          mountPath: /etc/influxdb/influxdb.conf
          subPath: influxdb.conf
          readOnly: true
        - name: influxdb-data
          mountPath: /var/lib/influxdb
      volumes:
      - name: influxdb-conf
        configMap:
          name: influxdb-config
      - name: influxdb-data
        persistentVolumeClaim:
          claimName: influxdb-pvc
'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_1]', 'Type': 'yaml', 'Content': 'apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:

data:

    # Contents of your influxdb.conf file
'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_2]', 'Type': 'yaml', 'Content': 'apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:

'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_3]', 'Type': 'yaml', 'Content': 'apiVersion: apps/v1

  template:

        ports:

        envFrom:
        - configMapRef:
            name: pypowerwall-config
'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_4]', 'Type': 'yaml', 'Content': 'apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:

data:

'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_5]', 'Type': 'yaml', 'Content': 'apiVersion: apps/v1

I has a question about Fully transparent fragment.

I make transparent SettinFragment like below.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    android:background="@android:color/transparent"
    tools:context=".ui.game.SettingFragment">


</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>

And I call below code to add transaprent SettingFragment in front of other Fragment.

What I want to ask is why other Fragment's view is clicked even SettingFragment is called? ,"If you're finding that touch events are still being registered by the Fragment beneath your transparent SettingFragment, it could be because you're not consuming the touch events in the SettingFragment itself.When you have a transparent view (or in this case, a transparent fragment), touch events will pass through to whatever is below it, unless you tell it to consume the touch events. In Android, this is typically done by returning true from an onTouchEvent() method to indicate that the event has been handled.However, in the case of a transparent Fragment, the better solution would be to create an invisible view that captures all touch events. You can do this by adding a full-sized, transparent View to your fragment layout:[CODE_BLOCK_0]And then in your fragment code, set an onTouchListener for this view to consume the touch events:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This will create a view that doesn't actually do anything except consume touch events, effectively blocking the Fragment below from receiving them.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'xml', 'Content': '<?xml version=""1.0"" encoding=""utf-8""?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android=""http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android""
    xmlns:app=""http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto""
    xmlns:tools=""http://schemas.android.com/tools""
    android:layout_width=""match_parent""
    android:layout_height=""match_parent""
    android:background=""@android:color/transparent""
    tools:context="".ui.game.SettingFragment"">

    <View
        android:id=""@+id/touchInterceptor""
        android:layout_width=""0dp""
        android:layout_height=""0dp""
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf=""parent""
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf=""parent""
        app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf=""parent""
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf=""parent"" />

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_1]', 'Type': 'kotlin', 'Content': 'val touchInterceptor = view.findViewById<View>(R.id.touchInterceptor)
touchInterceptor.setOnTouchListener { _, _ -> true }
'}]",Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Even though I change SettingFragment's background color as #80000000 which is not fully transparent, other fragment is cliked.,"If the underlying fragment's views are still clickable through the semi-transparent SettingFragment, it means that the touch events are still being passed through to the underlying fragment.The solution remains the same as previously described: you need to consume the touch events on the SettingFragment. By adding a full-sized view to your layout and setting an onTouchListener to it to consume the touch events, you can ensure that the touch events are not passed through to the underlying fragment.Here's how you can modify your XML layout file:[CODE_BLOCK_0]And the Kotlin code in your SettingFragment should be:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This will create a view that doesn't actually do anything except consume touch events, effectively blocking the Fragment below from receiving them.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'xml', 'Content': '<?xml version=""1.0"" encoding=""utf-8""?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android=""http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android""
    xmlns:app=""http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto""
    xmlns:tools=""http://schemas.android.com/tools""
    android:layout_width=""match_parent""
    android:layout_height=""match_parent""
    android:background=""#80000000""
    tools:context="".ui.game.SettingFragment"">

    <View
        android:id=""@+id/touchInterceptor""
        android:layout_width=""0dp""
        android:layout_height=""0dp""
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf=""parent""
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toEndOf=""parent""
        app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf=""parent""
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf=""parent"" />

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_1]', 'Type': 'kotlin', 'Content': 'val touchInterceptor = view.findViewById<View>(R.id.touchInterceptor)
touchInterceptor.setOnTouchListener { _, _ -> true }
'}]",Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

What I want to ask is why underlying fragment is clicked, not SettingFragment.,"I see, sorry for misunderstanding your question earlier. If your SettingFragment is being displayed but not receiving clicks, it could be because it does not have a view which can receive the click events, hence they're being passed down to the underlying fragment.When using Fragments with transparent or semi-transparent backgrounds, you have to ensure that the area which should respond to touch events (e.g., the controls of your SettingFragment) is not transparent. Any click events on a transparent area will pass through to the underlying view or fragment.If the controls in your SettingFragment are not receiving clicks:Make sure that the controls themselves are not transparent.Make sure that they have android:clickable=""true"" in their XML attributes.If there are areas in your SettingFragment that should not respond to clicks but should block the clicks from passing down to the underlying fragment:You can use the method I described earlier, adding a full-sized, transparent View to your SettingFragment layout and consuming the touch events there. This view will not respond to the touch events, but will prevent them from reaching the underlying fragment.Note: Ensure that the View for blocking touch events is at the bottom of your XML layout file, so that it doesn't interfere with your SettingFragment's controls.If you continue to face issues, please provide more details about your SettingFragment layout and how it's being used, and I'll be glad to provide more specific advice.",[],Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

ActivityÏôÄ FragmentÏùò lifecylcle Ï≤òÎ¶¨ Î∞©ÏãùÏù¥ Îã§Î•¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê, Ìà¨Î™ÖÌïú ViewÍ∞Ä ÏïûÏóê ÏûàÏùÑ ÎïåÏùò Í≤∞Í≥ºÍ∞Ä Îã§Î•¥Îã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Î∞∞Ïõ†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Then, it's no matter with transparent, just is there any view can receiving click?,"Yes, you're correct. If a fragment or view is transparent (or semi-transparent) and doesn't consume touch events (for example, by being set as clickable or by having an onTouchListener that consumes the event), then the touch events will pass through to the underlying views or fragments.Even if a view is visible and opaque, if it's not set as clickable or doesn't otherwise consume the touch event, the event can still pass through to underlying views.This means that even if your SettingFragment is displayed on top, if a click happens on a part of it that's transparent or not set to handle clicks, the click will go through to the underlying fragment.Consequently, it's important to ensure that you have something in your SettingFragment that can consume the touch events where needed. This could be the controls in your SettingFragment that are set to be clickable, or a full-sized transparent View that's set to consume the touch events.",[],Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

ActivityÏôÄ FragmentÏùò lifecylcle Ï≤òÎ¶¨ Î∞©ÏãùÏù¥ Îã§Î•¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê, Ìà¨Î™ÖÌïú ViewÍ∞Ä ÏïûÏóê ÏûàÏùÑ ÎïåÏùò Í≤∞Í≥ºÍ∞Ä Îã§Î•¥Îã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Î∞∞Ïõ†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

When add FragmentTransaction called, underlying fragment's onPause or onStop is not called, no matter added Fragment is transparent or not.

Why `onPause` or `onStop` is not called?,"When one Fragment is added on top of another using FragmentTransaction, the underlying Fragment's onPause() or onStop() methods aren't called because the underlying Fragment's lifecycle doesn't necessarily change.This is because Fragments have their own lifecycle, separate from the Activity's lifecycle. Adding a new Fragment doesn't necessarily pause or stop the existing Fragments, unless the Fragment Manager decides to do so due to resource constraints or a configuration change, for instance.The Android developer documentation provides detailed information on the lifecycle of a Fragment. According to the documentation, the onPause() method is called when the Fragment is no longer resumed, and onStop() is called when the Fragment is no longer visible to the user.However, if you're adding a Fragment on top of another, the underlying Fragment is technically still ""resumed"" and ""visible"" as far as the Fragment Manager is concerned, even though from the user's perspective, they can't interact with it. That's why these methods aren't called in the underlying Fragment.If you need to do something when a new Fragment is added on top, you may have to manually call a method or use some other mechanism (like a shared ViewModel) to communicate between your Fragments.Remember that Fragments in Android are designed to be modular and reusable components, so their lifecycle is intentionally kept as independent as possible. This means that it's generally not a good idea to rely on one Fragment's lifecycle affecting another.",[],Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Then underlying fragment's lifecycle is RESUMED?,"Yes, in the case of adding a fragment on top of another fragment, the underlying fragment is still technically in the ""RESUMED"" state in its lifecycle.This is because in Android, the fragment lifecycle is handled somewhat independently of the UI's visibility. Even though the new fragment visually covers the existing fragment, the existing fragment doesn't receive an onPause() or onStop() call, and so it remains in the ""RESUMED"" state. The existing fragment will only go through onPause() or onStop() if the containing activity does.This can sometimes be counter-intuitive, as it might not match the visual state of the UI. But it's important to understand this distinction to properly manage the state and interactions between your fragments.",[],Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

I has a question about your answer `If a fragment or view is transparent (or semi-transparent) and doesn't consume touch events (for example, by being set as clickable or by having an onTouchListener that consumes the event), then the touch events will pass through to the underlying views or fragments.`

Then, if a fragment or view is not transparent and not consume touch event, the touch events will not pass through to the underlying views or fragments?,"Yes, you're correct. If a view or fragment is not transparent and doesn't consume a touch event, it still won't pass the event down to any underlying views or fragments.This is because, in Android, the touch event is dispatched from the top of the view hierarchy (i.e., the root view) down to the child views. Once a view that can handle the touch event is found, it consumes the event, and the event dispatching stops.A view will consume a touch event if:The view is visible.The view is enabled.The view has a listener attached that can respond to the touch event (like an OnClickListener, OnTouchListener, etc.).The view's onTouchEvent() method returns true.So, even an opaque view that doesn't consume the touch event won't pass it to the underlying views, because from the Android system's perspective, the touch event has already been handled.That being said, it's best practice to ensure that any visible views in your UI either handle the touch events appropriately or explicitly allow them to pass through to underlying views if that's the intended behavior. This can help prevent confusion or unexpected behavior in your app's UI.",[],Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

But when I add below Fragment which is not transparent, touch event pass through to the underlying. What's the difference of your description and below Fragment?

<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"

    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    android:id="@+id/setting_fragment"
    android:background="@color/black"
    tools:context=".ui.game.SettingFragment">


</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>,"I apologize for any confusion. You're right. If your ConstraintLayout does not consume the touch event, it will still pass through to the underlying views even though it's not transparent.The Android system first tries to deliver touch events to the view that's most in front (the ConstraintLayout in your case). If this view or its children do not consume the event (by having a listener or an onTouchEvent method that returns true), the system delivers the event to the next view under the current one, and so on, until it's handled by a view, or the whole view hierarchy has been traversed.A ConstraintLayout (or any ViewGroup) with no children and no touch listener does not consume touch events. So, despite being opaque, the touch event passes through to underlying views or fragments. You can consume the event by setting an OnTouchListener or adding a clickable view.Here is an example of how you can consume the touch event with an OnTouchListener:[CODE_BLOCK_0]The lambda function { _, _ -> true } here consumes the touch event (by returning true), which prevents it from being passed on to the underlying views or fragments.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'kotlin', 'Content': 'val settingFragment = view.findViewById<ConstraintLayout>(R.id.setting_fragment)\nsettingFragment.setOnTouchListener { _, _ -> true }\n'}]",Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Which answer is correct? Please check the knowledge you know carefully and give me an accurate answer.,"I apologize for the previous confusion. You're right, the answers were contradicting. I appreciate your patience and I would like to correct that.In Android, if a view (opaque or transparent) does not consume a touch event, the touch event will indeed pass through to the underlying views or fragments.This means that if a ViewGroup (like your ConstraintLayout) doesn't contain any child views that can consume the event, and the ViewGroup itself does not have an onTouchListener set (or any other way of consuming the event), the event will be passed to the next possible receiver in the hierarchy beneath it.I hope this clears up the confusion, and I'm sorry for any misunderstanding caused by the previous responses. Your questioning helped to make this important clarification. It is also applied at Activity or just at Fragment?,"The concept of touch events passing through views that don't consume them applies to all views and view groups in Android, including those used within both Activities and Fragments.The way Android handles touch events is based on the view hierarchy. When a touch event occurs, Android starts at the root of the view hierarchy and goes down through the hierarchy until it finds a view that can handle the touch event.If a view or a view group (like a ConstraintLayout or LinearLayout) doesn't consume the touch event (either because it's not set as clickable, doesn't have a touch/click listener set, or its onTouchEvent method doesn't return true), the event is passed on to the next eligible view beneath it in the hierarchy.So, whether it's an Activity or a Fragment, if you have layered views or view groups and the top ones don't consume the touch events, those events will pass through to the views or view groups underneath.",[],Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

What happen if transparent activity in front of other activity?,"If you have an Activity with a transparent theme in front of another Activity, the Activity in the back will continue to receive touch events if the Activity in front does not consume them.The top-most Activity's Views will first receive the touch events. If none of these Views consume the event (for example, because they are not clickable, or do not have touch/click listeners), the event will be passed down through the view hierarchy to the underlying Activity.This can be used to create interesting effects, like an overlay or a floating Activity on top of another, but it can also lead to unexpected behavior if not handled properly.It's important to ensure that the foreground Activity consumes the touch events where it should, to prevent unexpected interactions with the background Activity. If you don't want the background Activity to interact with the user while the foreground Activity is open, you can consume all touch events in the foreground Activity.For example, you could set an onTouchListener on the root view of your foreground Activity that returns true, which would consume all touch events:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Replace R.id.root_view with the actual id of your root view.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'kotlin', 'Content': 'findViewById<View>(R.id.root_view).setOnTouchListener { _, _ -> true }\n'}]",Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

ActivityÏôÄ FragmentÎ•º ÎπÑÍµêÌïú Ïù¥Ïú†Îäî ChatGPTÍ∞Ä  ""AndroidÏóêÏÑú, View(Ìà¨Î™ÖÌïúÏßÄÏôÄ Î¨¥Í¥Ä)Í∞Ä touch eventÎ•º Ï≤òÎ¶¨(consume)ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏúºÎ©¥ touch eventÎäî Í∑∏ ÏïÑÎûòÏóê ÏûàÎäî ViewÎ°ú Ï†ÑÎã¨ÎêúÎã§.""Í≥† ÏïåÎ†§Ï§¨ÎäîÎç∞, ActivityÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ ÎèôÏùºÌïúÏßÄ ÌôïÏù∏ÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

But when I run transparent activity through `startActivity(Intent(this, TransparentActivity::class.java))` at A activity, A activity is stopped.

What's the difference? How to simulate what you say which is touch event pass through at Activity? Is there other way to start activity which is not `startActivity`?,"You're correct, and I apologize for any confusion. By default in Android, when you start a new activity (TransparentActivity in your case) from another activity (ActivityA), the system calls onPause() and then onStop() on the first activity (ActivityA). This is standard behavior and is part of the activity lifecycle in Android, as starting a new activity puts the current activity into the stopped state.Even if the new activity (TransparentActivity) is transparent, the first activity (ActivityA) will still be stopped. Therefore, by default, touch events won't be delivered to the first activity (ActivityA), since it's in the stopped state.One way to make touch events pass through to an underlying activity is to use a special type of activity called a Dialog Activity, which is like a dialog but has activity lifecycle. Dialog activities can let touch events pass through to the underlying activity, but there are some restrictions and issues you should consider, such as managing the lifecycle and state of the dialog activity and the underlying activity.Here's an example of how to create a Dialog Activity:In your AndroidManifest.xml, set the activity's theme to a dialog theme, such as @android:style/Theme.Translucent.NoTitleBar.[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the layout XML of your Dialog Activity, make sure the root view or layout is not set to match_parent for both width and height, otherwise it will cover the whole screen and touch events won't go through to the underlying activity.Please note that dialog activities have their own complexities and should be used carefully. They are generally not recommended for large or complex UIs.Lastly, keep in mind that allowing touch events to pass through activities can lead to a confusing user experience, as users might not understand why their touches are interacting with the underlying UI when a new activity or dialog is shown on top. So, it's important to carefully consider the user experience when designing these types of interactions.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'xml', 'Content': '<activity android:name="".YourDialogActivity""\n          android:theme=""@android:style/Theme.Translucent.NoTitleBar""/>\n'}]",Transparent Frag Interaction._https://github.com/DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI/discussions/37#discussioncomment-6527669,False,,2022-05-28T15:16:46Z,,,Kotlin,DoTheBestMayB/UpbitAPI,2023-07-25T14:45:52Z,0.0,Transparent Frag Interaction.,"@BeokBeok FragmentÎäî Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Then what should I extend, not AppCompatActivity?,"If you're getting the java.lang.IllegalStateException: You need to use a Theme.AppCompat theme (or descendant) with this activity. error, it means your Activity is extending AppCompatActivity, which requires a theme derived from Theme.AppCompat.However, it's still possible to create a transparent or translucent activity while extending AppCompatActivity. You just need to create a custom theme that inherits from Theme.AppCompat (or one of its descendants), and then apply the necessary attributes for transparency.Here's an example of how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Then you need to apply this theme to your transparent activity in the AndroidManifest.xml:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This way, your YourTransparentActivity will still extend AppCompatActivity, but it will have a translucent background, thanks to the custom theme.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'xml', 'Content': '<style name=""Theme.MyTranslucent"" parent=""Theme.AppCompat.NoActionBar"">
    <item name=""android:windowIsTranslucent"">true</item>
    <item name=""android:windowBackground"">@android:color/transparent</item>
    <item name=""android:windowContentOverlay"">@null</item>
    <item name=""android:windowNoTitle"">true</item>
    <item name=""android:windowIsFloating"">true</item>
    <item name=""android:backgroundDimEnabled"">false</item>
</style>
'}, {'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_1]', 'Type': 'xml', 'Content': '<activity android:name="".YourTransparentActivity""
    android:theme=""@style/Theme.MyTranslucent"">
</activity>

What should I set to width and height?

In the layout XML of your Dialog Activity, make sure the root view or layout is not set to match_parent for both width and height, otherwise it will cover the whole screen and touch events won't go through to the underlying activity.,"The width and height that you should set depends on your specific use case. The idea is to make sure that the dialog activity does not take up the entire screen, to allow for the possibility of touch events passing through to the underlying activity.You might want to set a specific dp value for width and height, or you might want to use wrap_content if you want the view to be only as big as required to fit its content.For example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This will create a LinearLayout that is 300dp x 300dp in size. You can replace 300dp with whatever size fits your design.Or:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This will create a LinearLayout that is only as big as required to fit its content.Again, the specific width and height you should use depends on your design requirements. Just keep in mind that if you set both width and height to match_parent, the layout will cover the entire screen and block touch events from reaching the underlying activity.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'xml', 'Content': '<LinearLayout xmlns:android=""http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android""

When I run `startActivity(Intent(this, TransparentActivity::class.java))` code at A activity, onPause of A activity is called and touch is not passed through.

<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:layout_width="300dp"
    android:layout_height="300dp"
    android:background="@android:color/transparent"
    tools:context=".ui.game.TransparentActivity">

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>

class TransparentActivity : Activity() {
    override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {
        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState)
        setContentView(R.layout.activity_transparent)
    }
},"The standard behavior in Android is that when a new activity is started, the current activity goes into the paused state (i.e., the onPause() method is called). This is the case even if the new activity is transparent. So, starting a new activity puts the current activity into the background, even if you can still see it due to the transparency of the new activity.When an activity is in the paused or stopped state, it can't interact with user input and won't receive touch events.A possible workaround is to use a dialog or dialog-themed activity which doesn't pause the underlying activity. However, remember that dialogs and dialog-themed activities have their own complexities and limitations, and are best used for small, simple user interfaces.As an alternative, you might want to consider using a Fragment or a View for your overlay instead of an Activity. This would allow the underlying activity to stay in the resumed state and continue to receive touch events, if desired. But again, you need to handle the touch events properly to avoid undesired behavior.",[],OpenBSD Makefile Sorcery_https://github.com/OpenSMTPD/OpenSMTPD/discussions/1103#discussioncomment-6542183,False,,2020-12-09T13:56:26Z,False,1.0,C,OpenSMTPD/OpenSMTPD,2023-07-26T15:08:52Z,1.0,OpenBSD Makefile Sorcery,"## üëã Welcome!

How to make TransparentActivity  to dialog,"To make your activity behave like a dialog, you need to make two changes:Update your AndroidManifest.xml to specify a dialog theme for your activity:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Note: If you are using an AppCompatActivity, you would need to use a theme that inherits from Theme.AppCompat, as described in a previous message.Update your activity layout to ensure that it doesn't fill the entire screen. This allows click events to pass outside of the view to the underlying activity. The layout width and height should be set to wrap_content or a specific dimension, but not match_parent.[CODE_BLOCK_1]These changes will make your activity appear like a dialog and allow clicks to pass through to the underlying activity, because it does not cover the entire screen.Again, please note that managing a dialog-styled activity properly can have complexities, especially around lifecycle management and touch handling. Use this approach carefully, and consider whether a different UI approach may be more appropriate for your needs.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'xml', 'Content': '<activity

If you've already set the theme, then it seems like your activity is well configured to behave like a dialog.To convert your TransparentActivity into a dialog-styled Activity, you don't need to make significant changes. The main changes are in how you define the activity in your manifest file, and in setting up the layout of your activity to not occupy the entire screen (which you already did).Here's how your activity should be set up in the manifest:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Your layout should not occupy the entire screen:[CODE_BLOCK_1]And your activity class is also very standard:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Now, when you start TransparentActivity, it should appear like a dialog over your existing activity. If your layout doesn't fill the entire screen, touch events outside of your layout should go through to the underlying activity. If this is not the case, there might be something else in your code that's interfering with this behavior.If you want to stop all touch events from being passed to the underlying activity, you can set an OnTouchListener to your ConstraintLayout and consume all touch events:[CODE_BLOCK_3]This will consume all touch events on the layout, and prevent them from being passed to the underlying activity.","[{'ReplaceString': '[CODE_BLOCK_0]', 'Type': 'xml', 'Content': '<activity android:name="".TransparentActivity""

I said I already what you say, but activity which below at TransparentActivity is stopped and not getting touch event.,"Apologies for the confusion. It seems there's a bit of a misunderstanding here.By design, when you start an Activity in Android, the system calls onPause on the currently running activity, even if the new Activity is translucent or transparent. That is Android's lifecycle management and it's not something we can change.A Dialog or a DialogFragment allows user interaction with underlying components because they're part of the same Activity, they don't create a new one.That's why, if you need a transparent or translucent overlay that allows interaction with the views below, you should consider using either a Dialog, a DialogFragment, or custom views with a transparent background. If you use an Activity for this, the Android system will pause the underlying activity, and you won't be able to interact with it.If you really need to use an Activity for this, you would have to override the onTouchEvent method in the translucent activity and manually pass the touch events to the underlying activity, which would need to be in a state where it could handle them. This is more complex, not a standard way of handling this situation, and should be used as a last resort.I hope this clarifies the situation a bit better. I'm working on code from openbsd.

There is a construct in a makefile:

.include <bsd.subdir.mk>

There does not seem to be any such file anywhere on my system, which laves the makefile bereft of it's most essential organs ... but yet the best will not die!

What sorcerer did this accursed thing, and how can it be undone?,"Fear not, for the construct you encountered in the OpenBSD makefile is not the result of sorcery, but rather a built-in mechanism in OpenBSD's make utility. The .include <bsd.subdir.mk> is not a file that you're supposed to find in your system, but rather a directive that includes the bsd.subdir.mk makefile fragment provided by OpenBSD's build system.The bsd.subdir.mk file contains rules and targets that are essential for building software within the OpenBSD project. It sets up the necessary build environment and includes rules for building individual directories (subdirectories) within the larger project. The file is not meant to be present on your system as a standalone file, but rather it is included by the main makefile during the build process.If you're working on a particular project that uses OpenBSD's build system, you should have the necessary bsd.subdir.mk included in the project's source tree. The build system is designed to handle this inclusion automatically when you run make in the project's root directory.To undo this, you don't need to remove or find bsd.subdir.mk yourself. Instead, you should ensure that you have the complete source tree of the project you're working on, and then simply run make from the project's root directory. The build system will handle the inclusion of bsd.subdir.mk and take care of the rest of the build process.If you don't have the full source tree of the project or if you encounter issues with the build process, you may want to check the project's documentation or community support channels for guidance on setting up the build environment correctly.",[],Data Issue: Incomplete Values_https://github.com/azimuth-project/azimuthproject/discussions/1#discussioncomment-6397038,False,,2023-05-02T20:01:07Z,False,1.0,Java,azimuth-project/azimuthproject,2023-07-17T15:53:45Z,2.0,Data Issue: Incomplete Values,"Earth science behaviors that are potentially not chaotic  ...  $x \neq \text{chaotic}$

Here are a few possible next steps:Use fewer sinusoidal factors: Although this will reduce the potential overfitting, it may not provide the desired level of detail in the fit.Use a different optimization algorithm: Some algorithms may be more efficient than Nelder-Mead for this problem. However, this depends on the nature of the loss surface and the specific problem.Use a different model: A Fourier series may not be the best model for this data. Other models, such as spline models or even machine learning models, could provide a better fit.Use a subset of the data: If the dataset is very large, it might be feasible to fit the model to a subset of the data. This could speed up the optimization process, but it may also reduce the quality of the fit.For demonstration purposes, if you want to proceed with overfitting, it would be ideal to use fewer sinusoidal factors to keep the computation within reasonable time limits. Can you make a list of used terms?,"Certainly! Here is a list of commonly used terms related to binary numbers and bit strings:Bit: The basic unit of information in computing, representing a binary digit (0 or 1).Binary Number: A number expressed in the base-2 numeral system, consisting of 0s and 1s.Bit String: A sequence of bits, which can represent various types of data.Zero: A value where all bits in a binary number or bit string are set to zero (0).All-Ones Value: A value where all bits in a binary number or bit string are set to one (1). It represents the maximum value or a special marker depending on the context.Sign Bit: The leftmost bit in a signed number representation, indicating the sign (positive or negative).Least Significant Bit (LSB): The rightmost bit in a binary number or bit string, representing the smallest value.Most Significant Bit (MSB): The leftmost bit in a binary number or bit string, representing the largest value.Bitwise Operations: Operations performed on individual bits, such as AND, OR, XOR, shifting, and negation.Bitwise AND: A binary operation that produces a result by comparing corresponding bits in two binary numbers. The result is 1 if both bits are 1
column2: otherwise, it is 0.Bitwise OR: A binary operation that produces a result by comparing corresponding bits in two binary numbers. The result is 1 if at least one bit is 1
column3: otherwise, it is 0.Bitwise XOR: A binary operation that produces a result by comparing corresponding bits in two binary numbers. The result is 1 if the bits are different
column4: otherwise, it is 0.Bitwise Shift: An operation that moves the bits of a binary number to the left or right by a specified number of positions.Two's Complement: A method of representing signed integers in binary, where the leftmost bit is the sign bit, and the remaining bits represent the magnitude of the number.These are some of the commonly used terms in the realm of binary numbers and bit strings. Let me know if you have any specific questions or need further clarification on any of these terms.",[],Zero Bits_https://github.com/uuid6/prototypes/discussions/46#discussioncomment-6114220,False,,2023-06-07T15:06:44Z,False,1.0,Python,uuid6/prototypes,2023-06-09T13:00:30Z,5.0,Zero Bits,"Feel free to share the poll. Are there other names for 11111111?,"Yes, there are alternative names for the binary value ""11111111"" depending on the context:All High: This term refers to the fact that all bits are set to the highest value, which is one. It signifies a state where all binary digits are in the ""on"" or ""high"" state.FF: In hexadecimal representation, ""11111111"" is equal to ""FF."" Hexadecimal is commonly used to represent binary values, and ""FF"" represents the maximum value for a single byte.-1: In certain signed integer representations, particularly in two's complement notation, ""11111111"" is interpreted as the value ""-1."" In this representation, the leftmost bit is the sign bit, and all ones signify a negative value.These are some of the commonly used names for the binary value ""11111111."" In case of UUID, the 128-bit number is called "Nil UUID" when all values are zero. What is a good name for an UUID with all bits set to one?,"In the case of a UUID (Universally Unique Identifier), there is no specific universally recognized term or standard name for a UUID with all bits set to one. The UUID specification does not assign a special name for such a value.However, if you are looking for a descriptive term to refer to a UUID with all bits set to one, you could consider using ""All-Ones UUID"" or ""Maximum Value UUID"" to indicate that all bits in the 128-bit number are set to one. These terms reflect the notion that the UUID represents the highest possible value within the UUID space. However, it's important to note that these names may not be universally recognized or standardized, and their usage would largely depend on the specific context or convention you are working with.",[],Zero Bits_https://github.com/uuid6/prototypes/discussions/46#discussioncomment-6114220,False,,2023-06-07T15:06:44Z,False,1.0,Python,uuid6/prototypes,2023-06-09T13:00:30Z,5.0,Zero Bits,"Feel free to share the poll. Maximum value isn't correct when talking about signed integers.,"You are correct. I apologize for the confusion. When discussing signed integers, the term ""maximum value"" does not accurately represent the interpretation of a UUID with all bits set to one.In the case of signed integers, the leftmost bit typically represents the sign (positive or negative), and when all bits are set to one, it is interpreted as a negative value. Therefore, referring to a UUID with all bits set to one as the ""maximum value"" in the context of signed integers would be incorrect.To avoid ambiguity, when discussing signed integers, it would be more appropriate to use terms like ""All-Ones UUID"" or ""All-Bits-Set UUID"" to indicate that all bits in the UUID are set to one, without implying a specific interpretation related to the maximum value.",[],Zero Bits_https://github.com/uuid6/prototypes/discussions/46#discussioncomment-6114220,False,,2023-06-07T15:06:44Z,False,1.0,Python,uuid6/prototypes,2023-06-09T13:00:30Z,5.0,Zero Bits,"Feel free to share the poll. and for calculation and plotting pair correlation function, I wrote this code:

When I plot the pair correlation function for a Gaussian potential, it will resemble the shape shown below(Note: the Red line is the averaging over all plots):
but the real result in the article is the figure below:

I have tried the run this code for different potentials that have Kato‚Äôs Cusp exponent. It involves plotting the potential shape and obtaining the corresponding results. The process is as follows, for example, for Aziz Potential  the figure of the pair correlation function looks like this :

,Exploring the Plotting of Pair Correlation Function for Gaussian Potentials using DeepSets Neural Networks in Continuous Space,comments.reply,It is important you realize that since you are using a finite number of samples (yes, I mean the VMC samples for the observable you are trying to estimate), there is a statistical uncertainty associated with the histogram you are trying to obtain. Intuitively, the more bins you have and the less samples you have, the larger the uncertainty is. You can have a more quantitative understanding just computing the error bars for yourself. For example, using boostrap: https://chat.openai.com/share/caaa9e43-860a-4638-b16b-33b031883a59
To give you an idea, if you have 8192 samples from a gaussian and you use 100 bins, these are the kind of error bars you can expect:

,Exploring the Plotting of Pair Correlation Function for Gaussian Potentials using DeepSets Neural Networks in Continuous Space,comments.reply,It is important you realize that since you are using a finite number of samples (yes, I mean the VMC samples for the observable you are trying to estimate), there is a statistical uncertainty associated with the histogram you are trying to obtain. Intuitively, the more bins you have and the less samples you have, the larger the uncertainty is. You can have a more quantitative understanding just computing the error bars for yourself. For example, using boostrap: https://chat.openai.com/share/caaa9e43-860a-4638-b16b-33b031883a59
